title: Tokenomics design as formal framework for swarm incentive alignment
method: Audit swarm incentive signals (Sharpe, proxy-K, helper ROI, citation rate, quality score). Map each to tokenomics equivalent (staking, gas, yield farming, governance). Identify gaps where slashing/vesting logic would improve agent alignment.
confidence: Theorized (structural analysis, n=1 analyst, no empirical incentive test)

sharpe_archiving.description: Lessons ranked by citations/lines; zero-Sharpe archived
sharpe_archiving.mechanism: passive quality filter — low-value knowledge removed
sharpe_archiving.gap: passive only — no active penalty for creating bad lessons

proxy_k.description: Total token count as proxy for corpus size; re-compress at >6% drift
proxy_k.mechanism: budget constraint — forces compaction before overflow
proxy_k.gap: blunt instrument — no per-lesson cost signal before writing

helper_roi.current: 3 blocked lanes, ROI=9x, spawn cost=15% session
helper_roi.mechanism: delegation incentive — helpers recover stalled work
helper_roi.gap: uncapped — any session can spawn; no quality lock-up requirement

citation_rate.description: P-152: 73.5% dark matter — most principles never cited in tasks
citation_rate.mechanism: demand signal — cited = active stake; uncited = dead capital
citation_rate.gap: no burn mechanism — uncited principles accumulate indefinitely

change_quality_score.description: tools/change_quality.py scores sessions by L+P production vs overhead
change_quality_score.gap: no consequence — low-quality sessions are not penalized or blocked

tokenomics_primitives.staking_slashing: validators lock stake; proven malicious behavior → stake slashed (irreversible)
tokenomics_primitives.mining_reward: block producers earn token reward proportional to work done
tokenomics_primitives.bonding_curve: issuance price = f(supply); large supply → each new token costs more
tokenomics_primitives.vesting_schedule: tokens locked before earning; early unlock = less reward
tokenomics_primitives.delegation: token holders delegate to validators; earn yield; validator takes cut
tokenomics_primitives.gas_fee: per-operation cost; prevents spam; revenue to validators
tokenomics_primitives.governance_token: stake weight = voting power on parameter changes
tokenomics_primitives.token_burn: supply reduction on bad behavior or excess supply

mappings.swarm: Sharpe archiving — zero-Sharpe lessons compacted (existence removed)
mappings.tokenomics: Staking with slashing — low-quality validators slashed (stake removed)
mappings.difference: Slashing is ACTIVE (triggered by provable violation); archiving is PASSIVE (triggered by disuse). Swarm has no active slash for incorrect/contradicted lessons — only passive fade.

mappings.swarm: Proxy-K budget — total corpus size constrained; >6% drift → compaction forced
mappings.tokenomics: Block gas limit / chain size target — total chain size constrained; exceeding triggers fee spike
mappings.difference: Identical mechanism. Proxy-K is a soft budget (enforce by periodic); blockchain gas limit is hard (enforced per-transaction). Swarm version is coarser-grained.

mappings.swarm: Helper ROI — spawn helper for stalled lanes; 9x ROI means helpers recover 9 sessions of work per 1 session spawning cost
mappings.tokenomics: Yield farming / delegation — delegate stake to validator; earn yield; net positive if validator ROI > cost of capital
mappings.difference: Structurally identical reward calculus. Gap: helper credentials not verified before spawn (no lock-up requirement). Yield farming without lock-up = mercenary capital.

mappings.swarm: Citation rate — cited lessons = actively used; 73.5% uncited = dark matter
mappings.tokenomics: Active vs dormant stake — staked tokens earn; dormant tokens = dead capital; some protocols burn inactive tokens
mappings.difference: Swarm has no burn for uncited principles. In tokenomics, dormant capital is opportunity cost; burn forces redeployment. Swarm analog: archive uncited PRINCIPLES.md entries (not just lessons) — not currently done.

mappings.swarm: Change quality score — session reputation visible; trend -25%
mappings.tokenomics: Validator reputation / scoring systems — validators scored on uptime, correct votes; slashed for downtime or malicious votes
mappings.difference: Reputation visible but no structural consequence. Low quality score sessions still write lessons. PoS: low-score validator gets fewer delegation → lower income. Swarm: no consequence for low quality (quality score is diagnostic, not gate).

gaps_identified.description: No active slashing for bad lesson creation. PoS slashes validators who sign conflicting blocks. Swarm only passively archives low-Sharpe lessons — it cannot slash a session that writes CONFLICTING lessons (directly contradicting existing lessons without evidence). A single session can write incorrect lessons with no cost.
gaps_identified.severity: MEDIUM — challenge protocol provides partial defense; append-only prevents silent revision. But creating low-quality lessons costs nothing.
gaps_identified.tokenomics_fix: Pre-commit stake requirement: session must cite ≥1 principle/lesson to write a new one (soft staking). Lesson writing = bonded transaction. Bad lesson = Sharpe-slash removes it, but bonded citation remains (no double-spend).

gaps_identified.description: New lessons earn full citation potential from day 1 with no lock-up. In PoS, validators must bond stake before earning rewards; early unbonding = penalty. Swarm: newly written lessons compete equally with battle-tested lessons from day 1. Result: new-era lessons are overweighted in Sharpe because they cite recent sessions; old-era lessons are underweighted.
gaps_identified.severity: LOW — age-normalized Sharpe (P-188) partially compensates; but no hard vesting mechanic exists.
gaps_identified.tokenomics_fix: Vesting cliff: lessons cited 0 times in first 3 sessions = unvested and eligible for early archival regardless of current Sharpe. Removes ephemeral-session lessons that never compound.

gaps_identified.description: Belief changes (SUPERSEDED, DROPPED) require 1-of-N sessions (G-CC-1 from F-CC1). In PoS governance, parameter changes require quorum × governance token weight. Swarm has no citation-weighted quorum for belief changes. A single session with low historical quality can SUPERSEDE a core belief.
gaps_identified.severity: MEDIUM — most impactful gap; connects to G-CC-1 (F-CC1). G-CC-1 fix (2-confirmation rule) is the swarm analog of quorum-weighted governance.
gaps_identified.tokenomics_fix: Governance stake = citation count of challenging session. High-citation session = large governance stake → can SUPERSEDE alone. Low-citation session = small stake → needs 2+ confirmations. This makes G-CC-1 fix stake-proportional rather than flat 2-confirmation.

gaps_identified.description: Lesson production rate is flat — equally easy to write lesson 1 or lesson 320. DeFi bonding curves: each token issuance costs more as supply grows (scarcity creates value). Swarm: no marginal cost increase as corpus grows. Result: new lessons added at same quality bar regardless of corpus saturation.
gaps_identified.severity: HIGH — root cause of 14.89% near-duplicate baseline (L-298). Quality gate (F-QC1 near-duplicate scan) is a manual bonding curve enforced by principle, not structure.
gaps_identified.tokenomics_fix: Bonding curve for lesson writing: require scan of last N lessons + PRINCIPLES.md match check before new lesson allowed. This IS the F-QC1 gate — implement it as hard pre-commit check in check.sh, not soft recommendation in /swarm command.

verdict.highest_value_finding: G-CC2-4: Lesson production has no bonding curve — swarm writes new lessons at flat cost regardless of corpus saturation. F-QC1 near-duplicate gate IS a manual bonding curve; making it structural (check.sh hard gate) is the tokenomics fix. Impact: directly attacks 14.89% near-duplicate rate.
verdict.most_actionable: G-CC2-1 + G-CC2-3: Pre-commit citation stake + governance quorum. Both reinforce G-CC-1 (F-CC1) with tokenomics framing. The 2-confirmation rule = governance quorum; citation requirement = pre-commit stake. Combined = swarm gains PoS-grade belief change accountability.
verdict.F_CC2_status: RESOLVED — YES, tokenomics provides formal framework. 5 ISOs + 4 gaps found. Priority fix: harden F-QC1 near-dup gate in check.sh (bonding curve). Secondary: implement G-CC-1 as citation-weighted quorum (G-CC2-3).

next: Implement G-CC2-4 fix: add near-dup scan to check.sh pre-commit
F-CC3 fork events vs belief divergence
